content.description:
This is the imposing crack that follows the dihedral on the right side of the crag. Looks fun, and it is! Don't let the wide start deter you, there are plenty of ledges to aid your progress up to where the crack narrows to perfect hands and then tips. Didn't see anyone on this route while I was up and it didn't even warrant its own description in the guidebook which is a shame because it's a blast.

Impossible to miss. It's the large dihedral on the right of the crag.
A bit of a thinker, place your big stuff in the corner or small stuff in the little cracks that run up the right face? You'll have plenty of options, but you may want to save something small for the last 15 feet. Bolted anchors up top. Possibly could be top-roped?

Wide crack lower, nice movement to exit the crack into choosier middle that transfers into a finger crack at the end.Â 

It is the next crack to the right of '' Be Happy''.
SR to 4'' -- Only two bolt with no chains for the anchor

An easy climb with so many holds, it doesn't really need to be climbed as a crack. A nice way to get up to set Tilted Glass as top rope if that's desired. The route trends slightly right in the first half.



Right leaning crack feature directly right of Tilted Glass. Look to the right of the Tilted Glass bolts and blank face.

2 bolts at the top

The prominent crack on the face to the right of Lichen In My Panties. The crack varies in size from fists at the bottom, through hands, to fingers at the top allowing for practice in a variety of techniques. Or just use the abundant edges and features and skip using the crack entirely.

To the left of the large dihedral (Be Happy). Not to be confused with the two overgrown cracks on the far right of the crag.
Will swallow every piece you have up to a #4 C4, but with an emphasis on hand-sizes.

Easy climbing to the beginning of the crack starting a third of the way up the wall. Good protection opportunities in the crack. Shares bolted anchor with climb to the left.

Look for a set of ledges below a fist crack starting a third of the way up the wall.
Trad protection to a shared bolted anchor.

The righthand dirty crack.

The furthest right crack that's been "cleaned" at Another Buttress. To the right of all the bolt lines.
Gear required.

Fun short face climb. Good beginner lead.

The rightmost route before a mossy, chossy section.
5 bolts.

Very pleasant climb, top is a bit weird though. For accessing the anchors to setup a top rope, go through Red Tail instead of the obvious left side. Feels much safer.

Left of the big crack behind the tree.
4 bolts on route and 2 bolts at the top with chains for anchors.

Certainly the most popular route at the crag and a great intro to typical Skaha climbing. Make your way  up small edges and crimps to a series of fun and easy ledges. The most difficult moves are concentrated in the lower half of the route.

Follows the first line of bolts to the left of the large dihedral (Be Happy) and broken crack (Don't Worry).
8 bolts to sport anchors. Might be possible to set a top-rope from the Dogmatism area of Red Tail South above, but I haven't tried.

Start by climbing the short crack and step out on the face after the first bolt.

Starts at the short vertical crack to the right of Brief Encounter, the longer crack oriented diagonally right.
5 bolts.

Not terribly interesting, two runouts keep you on your toes.

Just to the left of Lichen in My Panties (which would be a better choice for novice leaders because of its friendlier bolting).
Book says 5, but possibly missing one. Run out. A #2 or #3 might help decrease the final runout, but still. Not the best choice for the new 5.8 leader.

Climb the face crack with plenty of features on either side. May be a bit of a stiff lead for someone new but it protects very well except for the last section at the top where it turns into an easy scramble.

The obvious face crack in the middle of the crag, left of the corner crack immediately next to it.
Standard rack to 3" with a bolted anchor.

Very well protected face climbing with good hands and feet.



Bolted face immediately left of 'dont worry' crack. First bolt is on the crack and then trends left.

9 bolts

Nice pockets lead to a nice ledge.

Just to the left of the crack feature on the right side of Crowbar Crag in Another Buttress.
4 bolts.

climbs.name: Pry Baby
climbs.fa: Russ Turner, Beth Wardlow, Lyle Thiede 2008

content.description:
Good warm up for beginners.

The leftmost route on the small brown buttress called Crowbar Crag, one of the three mini-crags at Another Buttress.
4 bolts plus anchors.

Easily protected crack climb. There are enough face holds and the crack is featured enough no crack technique needed. A good intro trad lead. Bring a couple bigger cams (#2 / #3)



This is a crack feature in the rock directly right of Peripheral Vision. The crack is broken halfway up the wall, looking like a very thin hourglass in vertical profile. Right facing, slightly.Â 

Takes good pro, a couple larger cams.

Layback the right-facing flake or step inside. Sit down and take a break halfway on the flake while you place protection; look behind the flake. Finishes on the face left of a small tree.

Behind the wooden bench.
A #4 can be placed behind the flake halfway. Smaller gear on top part.This route has been retro-bolted with 7 bolts.

Despite the polished look, this route involves a lot of technical edging and is quite enjoyable. Â Agreed with the description in the Bourdon guide, aÂ lot of gym climbers are gonna have a rough time unless they learned to use their feet.Â 

Approximately 15 ft right of the prominent offwidth (tick crack), clearly identified as a polished faceÂ 
Bolts
A popular crag with a nice mix of bolted and traditional lines in the 5.6-5.8 range. Shady throughout the day, so it's a good destination for those summer scorchers.
